head.title: Man Who Killed From Train Is Guilty

identified-content.classifier: Top/News/U.S./U.S. States, Territories and Possessions/New York

hedline.hl1: Man Who Killed From Train Is Guilty

block.p: A man from the Bronx was convicted of manslaughter yesterday in the 1991 shooting of a Lehman College student from a moving subway train, the Bronx District Attorney, Robert Johnson, said.
A Bronx jury found the man, Lawrence Sinclair, 21, guilty of one count of manslaughter for the death of the student, Paula Soto, 19, on March 19, 1991, Mr. Johnson said.
A man from the Bronx was convicted of manslaughter yesterday in the 1991 shooting of a Lehman College student from a moving subway train, the Bronx District Attorney, Robert Johnson, said.
A Bronx jury found the man, Lawrence Sinclair, 21, guilty of one count of manslaughter for the death of the student, Paula Soto, 19, on March 19, 1991, Mr. Johnson said.

Ms. Soto, of Riverdale, was on an athletic field at Lehman College warming up for a softball game when she was struck by shots fired from an elevated subway train a block away. She died a few hours later while undergoing surgery.

An anonymous tip led to Mr. Sinclair's arrest on Aug. 12, 1993. According to testimony, Mr. Sinclair was asked during a job interview whether he had ever shot anyone, and he admitted that he had fired shots while standing between two cars of a moving train, hitting a woman who later died. He was placed under police surveillance and later arrested.
Mr. Sinclair faces a maximum prison term of 5 to 15 years when Justice Martin Marcus of State Supreme Court sentences him Nov. 17.
